## Introduction
Animals_Washington_Townsend's_Big-Eared_Bat, also known as Townsend's Big-Eared Bat, is a species of bat found in North America. It is named after the American naturalist John Kirk Townsend, who first discovered and described the species. These bats are known for their large ears, which play a crucial role in their hunting and navigation.

## Physical Characteristics

They have distinctively large ears, which can measure up to 1.5 inches in length. The ears are used to enhance their hearing abilities and aid in detecting prey and navigating in the dark. The fur of these bats is typically brown or gray, providing camouflage in their natural habitat.

## Habitat and Distribution
Animals_Washington_Townsend's_Big-Eared Bats can be found in various habitats across North America, including forests, deserts, and grasslands. ## Behavior and Lifestyle
